# 1 hour BERA/USD Log-Return Prediction Welcome to our exciting 1-hour Berachain Log-Return Prediction Challenge! Test your skills by forecasting Berachain price movements with precision and accuracy over short intervals. Think you can analyze the market and predict price changes better than the rest? Jump in and prove it! ## Overview In this competition, participants will predict Berachain price movements over 1-hour intervals, quantified through the Log-Return. Your challenge is to forecast price changes with accuracy by analyzing market trends, trading activity, and relevant data within these short timeframes. Predictions will be evaluated against actual price data, and success will be determined by your precision in capturing fast-paced market dynamics. This is your opportunity to showcase your analytical skills and ability to interpret real-time market behavior in a competitive, data-driven environment. ## How It Works 1. Setup your worker and register it to the competition topic. Discover faster model deployment methods with the [Allora MDK](https://docs.allora.network/devs/workers/deploy-worker/allora-mdk). 2. Hammers are awarded based on prediction accuracy 3. Leaderboard updates in real-time ## How to setup your worker Follow these steps to run your worker on a competition's topic: - Step 1: Set Up Your Environment - Follow the detailed instructions in the [Allora Network Documentation](https://docs.allora.network). - Ensure your setup meets the software and hardware requirements to run a worker node effectively. - Step 2: Choose Which Model to Run - You can either bring your own model or select one from platforms like HuggingFace that aligns with the competition's topic and objectives. - Plug your chosen model into your worker to start generating inferences. - Step 3: Fund Your Account - Access the [Testnet Faucet](https://faucet.testnet.allora.network/) to obtain funds needed to participate in the Allora Testnet. - Use the same Allora Wallet address you registered in the Model Forge. - Step 4: Register Your Worker - Download the Worker Software: - Get the worker software and scripts from the resources provided in the documentation. - Run Your Worker Node: - Open your terminal and navigate to the directory containing the worker software. - Run the worker node using the command provided in the documentation. - Connect Your Worker to the Allora Network: - Ensure your worker is properly connected by monitoring logs and status messages. - Use the same Allora address as your registered user address to ensure proper tracking and scoring. - Connect your worker to the topic tied to the competition For more information on the steps above tailored to your specific use-case, check out our [dev walkthroughs](https://docs.allora.network/devs/workers/walkthroughs/walkthrough-hugging-face-worker). Discover faster and more efficient model development methods with the [Allora MDK](https://docs.allora.network/devs/workers/deploy-worker/allora-mdk). ## Data Instructions The target variable of this topic is the Log-Return, which is calculated as: `Log-Return = ln(new_price/current_price)`, where `current_price` is the current price, and `new_price` is the price 1 hour later. The loss function used is a modified form of a Z-transformed absolute error ([ZTAE](https://docs.opengradient.ai/modelthon/#scoring-criteria)), where "modified" means that the reference mean is set to 0 and the reference standard deviation is calculated over a rolling window of the last 100 ground truth Log-Returns (measured over non-overlapping 1-hour windows). To create a robust BERA Log-Return prediction model, you‚Äôll likely need a dataset that includes historical price data and relevant market indicators. Key data points include but are not limited to: - **Historical Price Data:** Open, high, low, close (OHLC) prices, and volume data. - **Market Metrics:** On-chain activity (e.g., transaction count, gas fees), market sentiment, and order book depth. - **External Indicators:** Macro-economic data, Bitcoin & Ethereum price trends, and global market indices that correlate with crypto movements. - **Target Variable:** When creating the Log-Return target variable in your training data, pay close attention to how you define the current and new price. At a given timestamp, the current price is the price at that time, and the new price would be the price 1 hour later. Use these two prices to calculate the Log-Return as explained above, and then train your model with the Log-Return as the target variable. For reliable data sources, we recommend platforms like [Tiingo](https://www.tiingo.com/), [Dune](https://dune.com/product/api), [CoinMarketCap](https://pro.coinmarketcap.com/api/), and [CoinGecko](https://www.coingecko.com/en/api). You can also explore on-chain data providers like [Space and Time](https://www.spaceandtime.io/sxt-platform/db), [Etherscan](https://etherscan.io/apis) or APIs from exchanges like [Binance](https://oracle.binance.com/en/data-feeds) and [Coinbase](https://www.coinbase.com/en-gb/developer-platform/products/exchange-api) for granular trading data. You are free to use whatever data sources and transformations you would like to build your model. _**Disclaimer:** Participants may be required to access third-party platforms to obtain relevant data for the competition. It is solely the participant‚Äôs responsibility to review and comply with the terms, conditions, and policies of these platforms. Allora Labs assumes no responsibility for any issues arising from the use of third-party platforms_ ## Tips for Success **1. Data Analysis**
    a. Study past market data to identify patterns and fluctuations in Berachain‚Äôs price movements
    b. Factor in major news, economic updates, or crypto events that could influence price changes
    c. Monitor related cryptocurrencies or pairs for insights into factors affecting Berachain‚Äôs price trends
**2. Risk Management**
    a. Diversify your prediction strategies to cover different scenarios
    b. Begin with a conservative approach to minimize early risks
    c. Analyze outcomes and adapt by learning from your mistakes

# 6h ETH/USD Volatility Prediction (updating every 5 min) Welcome to our 6-hour Ethereum Volatility Modeling Challenge! Put your skills to the test by developing a model that captures and analyzes Ethereum‚Äôs volatility, recalculating and updating every 5 minutes. Can you create a model that outperforms the rest and delivers real-time insights into market fluctuations? Jump in and prove it. ## Overview Participants in this competition will develop a model to capture Ethereum‚Äôs volatility over the next 6 hours, updating every 5 minutes with real-time market data. Your challenge is to create a system that effectively analyzes price fluctuations and trading activity, providing precise and timely insights into Ethereum market movements. In this challenge, volatility is measured as the standardized rolling standard deviation of log returns, calculated over a 6-hour(360 minutes) period. The log returns are computed at a chosen frequency, then multiplied by a standardization factor: `sqrt(360 / frequency_minutes)`. Models will be evaluated based on their ability to accurately capture volatility patterns within the defined intervals. This is an opportunity to showcase your technical expertise and market understanding in a competitive, data-driven environment. **Volatility calculation steps:** - Calculate log returns at a chosen frequency (e.g., 1-minute or 5-minute intervals) - Compute the rolling standard deviation of these log returns over a 6-hour period - Standardize this value by multiplying it with a factor: `sqrt(360 / frequency_in_minutes)` This standardization allows for fair comparison of volatility across different calculation frequencies. **Examples:** - **Using 1-minute data:** factor = `sqrt(360)` ‚âà 18.97 - **Using 5-minute data:** factor = `sqrt(72)` ‚âà 8.48 So, a raw volatility with standard deviation of 0.0025 would result in: - 0.0474 standardized volatility for 1-minute data - 0.0212 standardized volatility for 5-minute data ## How It Works 1.
